description: {"blocks":[{"key":"vvai","text":"This protocol describes hybridisation chain reaction (HCR) in situs in the eyes of zebrafish larvae \u003e4 dpf. It is broadly the same as the standard protocol from molecular instruments, with modifications to improve staining in the eye. This is necessary due to the poorer penetration of reagents into the eye compared to other tissues, such as the brain. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":59,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5bprn","text":"Raise larvae in embryo medium containing 0.003% of 1-phenyl 2-thiourea (PTU) to inhibit pigment development. Alternatively, bleaching with H2O2 can be performed post fixation, however our experience has so far been that better quality images are obtained with PTU-treated fish. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":140,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":142,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9t3l3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7q1jv","text":"PTU cannot completely inhibit RPE pigmentation at non-teratogenic concentrations, however the residual pigment still present tends to be cleared by the HCR buffers. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3goo3","text":"Fix larvae in 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) for 1-2 hours at room temperature.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e9nqi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1kha5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":234}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ee68h","text":"Shorter fixation times improve the penetration of reagents. This is more important for antibody staining, but should help improve HCR signals as well. If the target mRNAs are extremely abundant however, a normal overnight fixation at    should not be detrimental. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fhhdv","text":"A caveat of reduced fixation is that the samples are consequently more fragile and should be handled gently. See the end of the protocol for an important warning related to this.
